title: Westphalian (stage)
text:
The Westphalian is a <a href="Stage%20%28stratigraphy%29">stage</a> in the regional <a href="stratigraphy">stratigraphy</a> of northwest Europe with an age between roughly 313 and 304 <a href="Megaannum">Ma (million years ago)</a>. It is a subdivision of the <a href="Carboniferous">Carboniferous</a> <a href="system%20%28stratigraphy%29">system</a> or <a href="period%20%28geology%29">period</a> and the regional <a href="Silesian%20%28series%29">Silesian</a> <a href="series%20%28stratigraphy%29">series</a>. The Westphalian is named for the region of <a href="Westphalia">Westphalia</a> (<a href="German%20language">German</a>: "Westfalen") in western <a href="Germany">Germany</a> where strata of this age occur. The <a href="Coal%20Measures">Coal Measures</a> of <a href="England">England</a> and <a href="Wales">Wales</a> are also largely of Westphalian age though they also extend into the succeeding <a href="Stephanian%20%28stage%29">Stephanian</a>.
The Westphalian age is preceded by the <a href="Namurian">Namurian</a> stage/age (which corresponds to the <a href="Millstone%20Grit">Millstone Grit Series</a> of Great Britain) and succeeded by the Stephanian stage/age (which corresponds to the uppermost part of the <a href="Coal%20Measures">Coal Measures</a> of Great Britain). In the official <a href="geologic%20timescale">geologic timescale</a> of the <a href="International%20Commission%20on%20Stratigraphy">ICS</a>, the Westphalian is placed within the <a href="Pennsylvanian%20%28geology%29">Pennsylvanian</a> epoch (318-299 Ma).
The (regionally defined) Westphalian stage corresponds to the upper part of the (internationally used) <a href="Bashkirian">Bashkirian</a> stage together with the whole of the <a href="Moscovian%20%28Carboniferous%29">Moscovian</a> and <a href="Kasimovian">Kasimovian</a> stages. Frequent references appear in scientific literature to a Westphalian epoch or Westphalian <a href="series%20%28stratigraphy%29">series</a> reflecting the stage's earlier status.
Life.
<a href="Amphibian">Amphibian</a>s were diverse and dominated communities. The <a href="Rainforest%20collapse">collapse of the rainforest ecology</a> between the Moscovian and Kasimovian removed many amphibian species who did not survive as well in the cooler, drier conditions. Reptiles, however prospered due to specific key adaptations and underwent a major evolutionary radiation, in response to the drier climate that led to the rainforest collapse.
